e4: Transitioning to the no-bias policy resolves ethical concerns and could preempt any potential legal issues. Transparency is vital for maintaining integrity and investor trust. Over time, consistent communication about the change will help correct misconceptions, benefitting retail investors by fostering a fair marketplace and preventing information asymmetry, thus establishing broader credibility.
e5: An ethical reporting policy must adhere to transparency, honesty, and accuracy. It should present truthful financial performance figures without manipulation for stakeholder benefit. Accountability by correcting misreported data promptly ensures ongoing trust, while fairness protects all investor types from misinformation. Furthermore, considerations on material impact and legal compliance should be included.
e6: How does the management team plan to communicate and transition the policy change effectively to all investor demographics? What risk mitigation steps does the team foresee for individuals sensing short-term volatility effects when actual performance targets align more accurately with unbiased report deliverables? Could investor education initiatives further alleviate misunderstanding?
